history.content: As you noted, 105 is definitely more fundamental. If you have ever wanted to get a broad understanding of how circuits in "maker" projects work, then 105 will give you that knowledge. 105 is a good class to take if you found the circuits in 16A/B to be pretty easy and want to figure out how op-amps really work. If neither of these sounds like you, 105 probably isn't the right choice. 151 will teach you how various digital circuits work using the "transistor as a switch" model, and this is invaluable for anyone who would go into computer architecture or need to design circuits for something like DSP (digital signal processing). It's a good class to take if you enjoyed learning about timing restrictions and processor design in 61C. 151 usually entails a whole lot more work than 105 (although some instructors for 105 do their best to compete), so 120 and 151 would probably be more than enough for one semester, while 120 and 105 could leave room for one or two other significant endeavors.

children.subject: To give a slightly more fleshed out answer to your last question, the answer is no. The direction of learning is definitely from 105 to 151. 151 teaches a simplified version of circuits which allows people without in-depth understanding of them to analyze digital circuits, but will not allow students to analyze 105 (analog) circuits in the least. That being said, around 95% of CS-inclined students would get far more out of 151 than 105, considering that FPGAs could feasibly show up in a software engineer's work, while analog circuits (or device physics) likely never would. 105 really is a class that only makes sense for EEs and MechEs, etc. (people that interact with analog or power electronics).

history.content: Hi! I am doing scheduling for the rest of my berkeley career, and as a CS-oriented person, I also wish to get insights about the world of EE . I plan to teke EE 120 with one of 105 or 151. Frankly speaking, I don't know how much these two courses differ in content just by seeing the course title. If I can only choose one,  and I want to have an insight and open the "world" for EE world, and learn more staffs in a broad way, and possibly aid my CS career, which should I take?  If the suggestion is to take EECS 151, I'd also like to ask, can I also learn materials in EE 105 by taking EECS 151? Because 151 seem to be a more advanced class, I see it is interesting, but I also don't want to lose the chance to learn more fundamental, essential EE knowledge..
history.subject: Choose between EE 105 and EECS 151 as a CS major
